messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-08-30T22:03:24Z
## Message ID: 20180830-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20180828-AL-001 and 20180826-AL-004. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-08-26T18:40Z, and remain above 10^5 pfu, currently around 184,000 pfu. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream with ID 2018-08-26T07:00:00-HSS-001. 

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-08-26T18:40:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 22, 2018 - August 28, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-08-29T21:57:21Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-08-22T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-08-28T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180829-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs. 

Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=7 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=7 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-08-26T03:00Z-09:00Z.  This strong geomagnetic storm was associated with the arrival detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-08-25T06:00Z of the S-type CME (<500 km/s) that started on 2018-08-20T21:24Z (see notifications 20180826-AL-001 and 20180826-AL-002).  The CME arrival was also combined with a coronal hole high speed stream detected at DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-08-26 that increased geomagnetic activity to moderate levels with Kp=6 for the synoptic periods of 2018-08-26T15:00Z-18:00Z and 2018-08-27T15:00Z-18:00Z (see notification 20180827-AL-001).  Solar wind speed reached values of ~650 km/s on 2018-08-27.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt were elevated above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period on 2018-08-22 and crossed the threshold again starting at 2018-08-26T18:40Z.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 on 2018-08-22 were associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-08-19 (see notification 20180822-AL-001).  On 2018-08-26, the energetic electron fluxes were associated to the combination of the CME and coronal high speed stream arrival described above (see notifications 20180826-AL-003, 20180826-AL-004 and 20180828-AL-001).  Currently, these energetic electron fluxes are still elevated above the threshold of 10^5 pfu with values of 197,000 pfu.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the geomagnetic storm and energetic electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-08-29T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-09-04T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are several active regions present on the solar surface that could produce some flare and CME activity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the possible arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-08-30.  Currently, solar wind speed at DSCOVR/ACE is still slightly elevated at values of ~500 km/s due to the coronal hole high speed stream detected on 2018-08-26.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-08-28T22:21:27Z
## Message ID: 20180828-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with ID 20180826-AL-004. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-08-26T18:40Z, and remain significantly above 10^5 pfu, currently around 240,000 pfu. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the combined effects of the HSS with ID 2018-08-26T07:00:00-HSS-001 and the CME with ID 2018-08-20T21:24:00-CME-001.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-08-26T18:40:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-08-27T18:44:00Z
## Message ID: 20180827-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Intensifying space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2018-08-27T15:00Z to 2018-08-27T18:00Z. 

The storm is caused by the high speed stream starting on 2018-08-26T.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-08-27T15:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-08-26T14:43:22Z
## Message ID: 20180826-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Geomagnetic storm intensified in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic periods 2018-08-26T03:00Z to 2018-08-26T06:00Z and 2018-08-26T06:00Z to 2018-08-26T09:00Z. 

The storm is caused by the CME with ID 2018-08-20T21:24:00-CME-001.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-08-26T00:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 

This event is associated with the Interplanetary Shock with ID 2018-08-24T05:50:00-IPS-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-08-22T23:23:49Z
## Message ID: 20180822-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:
This is an update to the notification with Activity ID 2018-08-20T22:50:00-RBE-001 (see notification 20180820-AL-001).

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-08-20T22:50Z and has continued to be elevated or close to this threshold, currently at around 81,300 pfu. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-08-19T16:05Z, which reached a speed of around 670 km/s. The current solar wind speed is around 470 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-08-20T22:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 15, 2018 - August 21, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-08-22T21:49:18Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-08-15T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-08-21T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180822-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:
   
Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs. 
   
Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-08-15T12:00Z-15:00Z, 2018-08-15T21:00Z-2018-08-16T03:00Z, 2018-08-17T03:00Z-06:00Z,   2018-08-18T06:00Z-09:00Z, 2018-08-20T00:00Z-03:00Z and 2018-08-20T18:00Z-21:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of coronal hole high speed streams detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-08-14 and 2018-08-19. Solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2018-08-17 and ~650 km/s on 2018-08-20.

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-08-18T16:10Z and at 2018-08-20T22:50Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the two coronal hole high speed streams described above (see notifications 20180819-AL-001 and 20180820-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-08-22T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-08-28T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are two active regions present at the solar surface that have some potential for flares and CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the possible arrival of a S-type CME (<500 km/s) around 2018-08-25.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-08-20T23:17:12Z
## Message ID: 20180820-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-08-20T22:50Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2018-08-19T16:05Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-08-20T22:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 08, 2018 - August 14, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-08-15T17:22:22Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-08-08T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-08-14T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180815-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    
    
Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-08-11T21:00Z-24:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-08-11. Solar wind speed reached values of ~400 km/s on 2018-08-12.

DSCOVR/ACE at L1 also detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-08-08 and 2018-08-14. Solar wind speed reached values of ~450 km/s on 2018-08-08 and it is currently around ~500 km/s on 2018-08-15.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-08-08 and 2018-08-12. Solar wind speed reached values of ~450 km/s on 2018-08-09 and ~600 km/s on 2018-07-12.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-08-15T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-08-21T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are two active regions currently visible at the solar surface that have some potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. Currently, geomagnetic activity is slightly elevated with Kp=4 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-08-14.  There is also an expected arrival of another coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-08-19.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Summary:    

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.  
 
Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-07-28. Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2018-07-29.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES were highly elevated to values of 98,000 pfu around 2018-07-25, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period.  This elevation was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-07-24.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.
